instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.TPS51125: What is TPS51125? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1278 model Macbooks.

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
When I measure up in diode mode it give me 0.49
when i measure in V mode it give me 12.6 V and then slowly it's dropping. 
What does it means?

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
It means it is failing.....lol ;)

What board are you talking about???

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Check <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR>, should be 20ohm...... Also remove F7040 and see if voltage gets stable on pin 1....

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> is 20ohm. removed f7040 measured at pin one i get 12.5V for 3 seconds and it goes down to 5V slowly and then back again to 12.5 and so on

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Resistance between pin 17 and 18 and between pins 27 and 28 from <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.....

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Voltage on pin 2 from <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is stable??

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: 16.52V stable

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: ok, what about the other question, resistane between pins 17/18 and 27/28...

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Seems fine. Look around <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP> area, corrosion?

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Replace <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.........

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Don't touch <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> just yet. If <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is dead it should still power on from a battery that has a charge.

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: there's no corrosion around <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP>

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: i have a green light in the charger and that's it. any thoughts on this?

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: No, connect a battery that holds a charge and see if it will power on.

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Put back F7040 first of course....

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: i did connect a battery and still nothing...the F7040 is on the board

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Check resistance to GND on L7220 and check voltage on <RESISTOR>R7273</RESISTOR>. Do this without battery and on AC, see if it pulses.

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7273</RESISTOR> is 3.4V
L7220 1.71kohm

I was keep tracking where on the board it starts the voltage to drop and i find out on <TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR> at pin
1 i have 16.26V
2 is 16.26V
3 is 16.26
4 is 15.5 13.3 and 5.5V 
5 is 16V then 15 14 13V its dropping to 4 ad so on like <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Is 3V coming high on L7220 for a moment? I'm suspecting the 51125

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: 0V on the L7220

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Replace the 51125

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: replaced same problem <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> it's stable for 2 seconds and then it's dropping slowly

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is next then.
